screening_results.reason: The study used resting-state fMRI (rsFC) rather than an fMRI scan during a social-related task. While it examines social variables (peer/parent relationships) as predictors, there is no social-processing task performed during scanning, so it does not meet the task-based fMRI inclusion criterion.

Functional MRI was conducted while healthy adult couple dancers performed joint-action leader/follower tasks, a clear form of social interaction (perception/understanding of others, social communication). Participants are healthy adults; study is original research (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Task-based fMRI examining neural processing of race and socioeconomic status during social evaluation of faces in 61 white male participants. Addresses perception/understanding of others (social processing). No exclusion criteria met; abstract implies healthy adult participants. Include for full-text review to confirm age range and health status.

fMRI was conducted in 16 healthy adult volunteers viewing a movie of verbal and non-verbal social interactions, examining neural responses to social perception/interpretation. This directly fits the review objective; not a review or meta-analysis.

Title and abstract indicate oxytocin study examining neural (anterior insula) responses to positive social stimuli, implying an fMRI task targeting social processing in humans. Participant health/age not specified in abstract, but likely healthy adults; insufficient explicit detail warrants inclusion for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports event-related fMRI during a mind-perception task (social cognition) and subsequent social attention task; involves human participants and examines social-related neural processes. Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion; full-text can confirm participant ages/health but abstract strongly indicates healthy adult sample.

fMRI study with 34 healthy adult participants performing an empathic accuracy task (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study examining perception of intelligence and friendliness from faces — a social-perception task (Perception/Understanding of Others). Appears to involve healthy adult participants (no clinical groups mentioned). Age range not specified in abstract; insufficient detail to confirm ages, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study investigating neural mechanisms of social communication (categorization of prosodic intentions). Participants performed a social-related task (understanding communicative intentions). No indication it is a review or involves only clinical samples; likely healthy adult participants. Thus meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI was conducted while healthy adult participants made socially influenced decisions (free vs. controlled by another person). The study investigates social cognitions (distrust, understanding) and neural mechanisms of social processing in healthy adults, and is not a review.

Study reports functional MRI collected while participants performed emotion perception tasks (facial, vocal, bimodal) — a social-communication/perception task. Participants appear to be healthy adults and the study is empirical (not a review). Age not specified in abstract, so moderate confidence; include for full-text review.

Abstract describes an independent fMRI study comparing social vs. non-social image appraisal and uses neuroimaging ROIs—directly relevant to social processing. However, the abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Primary data fMRI study investigating perception of social interactions using point-light and moving-shape stimuli; participants appear to be healthy adults performing a social-related task (interaction vs non-interaction, competition vs cooperation). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

This is a chapter/review synthesizing existing behavioral and neuroimaging literature, not a primary fMRI study reporting original data on human participants performing a social task. Excluded as a review.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in healthy adult males performing social-cognition tasks (reflection on own and a friend's attributes). This directly matches inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI of social and emotion processing in a large cohort of healthy adults (Human Connectome Project, n=787). This directly meets the review objective of social-related fMRI in healthy adults and is not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (ages 25–50) but the task (viewing erotic pictures/videos) is not clearly described as a social-related task in the abstract. While some activations are linked to social cognition, information is insufficient to determine eligibility. Include for full-text review to confirm whether the task meets the review’s social-processing criteria.

fMRI study of improvised joint action involving social interaction (leading/following, mutual conditions) and reported social-cognition-related activations. Appears to involve healthy adult participants (trained dancers). Not a review; meets inclusion—include for full-text review.

fMRI study with 36 healthy adult subjects (within 17–65). Participants observed social interactions probing social cognition (cooperativity, affectivity). Empirical fMRI data collected during a social-related task; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy human participants performing collaborative vs. individual communicative tasks—addresses social communication/perception of others. Not a review. Abstract omits participant ages, but meets core inclusion criteria; include for full-text to confirm age range and details.

Original fMRI research examining neural responses to person-related and other social concepts (concrete and abstract social terms) in human participants; directly addresses social-related processing. Not a review or meta-analysis. Appears to involve healthy adult participants, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 20 (presumably healthy adult) participants performing a social decision-making task (modified prisoner's dilemma) probing Theory of Mind/social cognition. Fits inclusion: functional MRI during social-related task in healthy adults; not a review. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

7T fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=23) using attachment-related auditory narratives (social/affiliation processing) with task-related/rest-task-rest design and functional connectivity analyses of social approach network. Matches inclusion criteria (social-related task; healthy adults). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants performing a social evaluation task (in-group vs out-group politicians), addressing social cognition/perception of others. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

The study used resting-state fMRI (fALFF) rather than functional MRI acquired while participants performed a social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during social processing; this criterion is not met.

fMRI experiment assessing social-related processing (judging social orientation/potential for involvement from biological motion). Abstract indicates healthy participants but does not specify ages; insufficient demographic detail to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to verify participant ages/health.

fMRI was used while participants viewed a social task (moral dilemma about kin vs non-kin), probing social cognition (moral/emotional conflict, mentalizing). Subjects appear to be healthy adults; no review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports a human neuroimaging finding: a strong neural response in posterior superior temporal sulcus to stimuli depicting social interactions, indicating an fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults. Study is empirical, not a review, and fits the review objective and inclusion criteria.

fMRI was performed while healthy adult male participants (in romantic relationships) completed social-related tasks (IAT assessing attitudes toward adultery and a go/no-go task measuring executive control) and a dating/affiliation rating task. This directly assesses social/affiliation processing in healthy adults and is not a review.

fMRI study of phonological short-term memory using letters and fingerspelling; task examines language/visuomotor memory processes rather than social-related processing or social communication. Although participants are healthy adults, the study does not target social cognition or interpersonal communication.

Abstract reports a single-case (one subject) fMRI study. Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy participants (age 17–65); a single-subject does not meet the ‘group’ criterion. Not a review/meta-analysis.

Adult healthy participants (monogamous vs non-monogamous men) viewed romantic and sexual stimuli; neural activation to social/affiliative (romantic) stimuli was measured. This matches fMRI social-related task in healthy adults; no exclusion criteria met.

Original empirical fMRI study investigating theory-of-mind/mentalizing (social cognition) using tasks probing others’ beliefs and motivations. Involves healthy adult participants and is not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria for social processing fMRI studies.

This is a review/commentary on resting-state fMRI and social cognition rather than an original study reporting fMRI during social-related tasks. No human task-based fMRI data or participants performing social tasks are described, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating theory-of-mind (implicit vs. explicit belief processing), a social-cognitive task in humans; appears to involve healthy adult participants and reports neural activity—meets inclusion criteria and is not a review.

The abstract explicitly states this is a quantitative review labeling peak coordinates from prior fMRI studies rather than reporting new fMRI data collected in participants. This meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study with N=34 healthy adult participants engaging in social-emotional tasks (schadenfreude vs fremdscham) probing social cognition/neural circuits. Not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not specified—include for full-text verification of ages and health status.

fMRI study in healthy adults involving mental simulation of personally familiar others — a social cognition/task involving perception and understanding of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for the review.

Functional MRI was used while healthy adults (trustee role in the Trust Game) performed a social reciprocity task. The Trust Game is a social-processing paradigm (perception/understanding of others, affiliation). Participants were healthy adults and this is an original fMRI study, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports acquisition of fMRI data during a social decision-making task (integration of social influence and reward) with human participants. Task clearly involves social processing (information from other group members). Not a review/meta-analysis. Participant age not stated but likely adults; nonetheless fMRI and social task criteria met.

fMRI was used while participants decided to read or share news articles—a social task involving sharing, perspective-taking, and self-related processing (social cognition). Participants are human adults (healthy group implied) and this is an original neuroimaging study, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults using a social interaction task (telling jokes to make a listener laugh) that probes self-related and other-related processing (mPFC, auditory cortex, ventral striatum). It directly addresses social-related processing and is not a review or meta-analysis.

Functional MRI was used during an observe/imitate emotional faces task — a social perception/understanding of others paradigm — in healthy adult participants (final N=20). Not a review/meta-analysis and matches review objective.

fMRI experiment (n=17) involved mentalising/theory-of-mind tasks (social cognition) vs factual memory in human participants; appears to involve healthy adult subjects and is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study with 50 healthy adult participants performing retrieval of biographical/person knowledge—clearly a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail for inclusion.

Abstract describes neural mechanisms of social information sharing (social-related processing) and reports two studies; however it does not explicitly state fMRI or participant ages. Include for full-text review to confirm that a functional MRI scan was used and participants are healthy adults (17–65).

fMRI study measuring neural responses to faces and attention to emotional valence — a social perception/understanding task. Appears to involve human participants (likely healthy adults). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

This publication is a systematic review and meta-analyses of fMRI studies (not a primary fMRI study). The exclusion criteria explicitly exclude systematic reviews/meta-analyses, so it should be excluded.

This publication is a coordinate-based meta-analysis of fMRI studies (30 articles), which meets the exclusion criterion of being a systematic review/meta-analysis rather than a primary fMRI study with participants.

fMRI study in 40 healthy volunteers viewing masked/unmasked emotional faces (social/affiliation-relevant stimuli). This directly addresses social processing in healthy adults and is not a review. The abstract does not state exact ages (17–65 criterion), so full-text should confirm age range, but the study otherwise meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in humans assessing attribution of emotions (social perception/understanding of others) during tasks; meets social-related processing criterion. Abstract does not state participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm sample fits 17–65 healthy adults.

Study uses fMRI during an empathy-for-pain social task and reports neural and behavioral effects of acute stress on prosociality — fits social-related processing. Abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages (17–65), so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study of social cognition (mental state/mentalizing judgments) in healthy adult participants. Task involves social-related processing with neural measures; not a review/meta-analysis. Although exact ages aren’t listed, participants are described as healthy adults, so it meets inclusion criteria for healthy adult fMRI studies.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining mentalizing, empathy, and prosocial behavior—clearly a social-related task involving perception/understanding of others and affiliation. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion for full-text review.

Title and abstract indicate investigation of face recognition and its neural correlates, suggesting neuroimaging in healthy adults; however the abstract is truncated and does not explicitly state fMRI or participant ages. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to verify methods and sample.

This article is explicitly a review of neuroimaging studies, not an original fMRI study. It meets the exclusion criterion of being a review/meta-analysis and does not report primary fMRI data from healthy adults aged 17–65 in the abstract.

fMRI study with human participants examining social competition (a social-related process) and associated brain activity. No clinical population indicated, fits healthy adult sample range, and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

fMRI was conducted using a face emotional processing paradigm, which fits social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). The abstract does not report participant health status or ages (17–65), so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to determine if healthy adult participants were studied.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in healthy adult participants performing a social cognition task (processing kin vs friends), directly addressing social-related processing. Not a review/meta-analysis. Participant group (25 females) falls within target age range likely adults; criterion met.

fMRI study in humans explicitly investigating prosocial learning and empathy (perception/understanding of others), meeting the review’s social-processing requirement. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state ‘healthy’, but methods imply typical healthy participants; insufficient detail to confirm age range—include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

The study reports task-based fMRI during reappraisal of angry faces — a social perception/regulation task — and links neural activity to emotion regulation ability in healthy participants. This meets the social-related fMRI criterion and is not a review.

fMRI study of social decision-making (Prisoner’s Dilemma/cooperation) in a sample of healthy adult participants; directly assesses social processing and meets inclusion criteria for functional MRI in healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI study examining self–other processing (cooperation/competition) with neural findings (ACC, area 9), clearly social-related. The abstract does not state participant health status or ages; therefore include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adults (17–65).

fMRI study examining attachment-related social processing in healthy participants (N=25); task uses attachment vs. control scenes probing social cognition/mentalizing. Meets review objective and inclusion criteria. Age range not specified in abstract—include for full-text review to confirm ages (17–65).

Abstract reports fMRI experiments measuring social cognition during social economic games (Prisoner’s Dilemma, Ultimatum Game), directly addressing social-related processing. It is an original fMRI study (not a review). The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state they are healthy adults, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Study used fMRI during self-reference vs reference-to-others tasks (social cognition), matching review objective. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy adults, so inclusion cannot be ruled out; include for full-text review to confirm sample characteristics and eligibility.

Human fMRI study (n=20) examining neural responses to social-emotional situations (angry vs joyful) while viewing actors—directly addresses social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Not a review. Although age/health not explicitly stated, likely healthy adults; include for full-text to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study with 34 (presumably healthy adult) participants viewing naturalistic movie stimuli; results focus on dorsal medial PFC responses to social interactions—addresses perception/understanding of others (social processing). No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study using a modified Cyberball task that directly probes social exclusion and social evaluation—clearly examines social-related processing. Abstract does not explicitly report participant health status or ages; per screening rules, include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65) and extract details.

fMRI study of human participants performing tasks including a theory-of-mind (social attribution of belief) task, which meets the social-related task criterion. It is an empirical fMRI study (not a review); participant health status is implied (typical healthy subjects). Abstract lacks explicit age range, so include for full-text review to confirm ages and health.

fMRI was conducted while participants performed the Ultimatum Game, a social decision-making task (cooperation/affiliation). Study reports healthy adult interventions (no indication of clinical sample) and is empirical (not a review). Participant age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text confirmation.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (n=19) performing a social cognition/ToM task (REMICS) manipulating mental state inferences and contextual adjustments, which fits ‘perception and understanding of others’. Not a review. Age range not specified in abstract—include for full-text if needed.

Empirical fMRI study examining impression updating (perception/understanding of others), a social cognitive task. Participants appear to be healthy adults; study is not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study in which human perceivers were scanned while performing a social inference task (learning about others' emotions). Addresses perception/understanding of others, uses reinforcement-learning analyses, and appears to involve healthy adult participants. Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study of social cognition (agentic/communal self-evaluation and endorsement of others' evaluation) addressing perception/understanding of self; meets review objective. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65).

fMRI study examining theory-of-mind/social cognition (cooperation vs competition) in human participants; not a review. Although participant ages are not specified in the abstract, the study clearly addresses social processing in (presumably healthy) adults and meets inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to confirm age/health details.

Abstract reports neural-level analyses (dynamic causal modeling) of empathy and mentalizing in a large sample (N=178), indicating neuroimaging of social processes. However it does not explicitly state fMRI or participant health/ages. Unclear details warrant inclusion for full-text review to confirm fMRI and healthy adult sample.

This abstract describes a methodological fMRI study of large-scale brain network community structure during rest and unspecified task conditions; it does not report an fMRI task involving social-related processing or social cognitive constructs in healthy adults. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion of a social-related task.

Human fMRI study examining social-cognitive processes (empathy, perspective taking, attention shifts) during a charitable-giving task—directly relevant to social-related processing. No indication it is a review/meta-analysis. Although participant ages are not specified, the study reports behavioral and neuroimaging data from human participants, consistent with healthy adult samples; therefore include for full-text review.

Abstract reports neural correlates of mentalizing and links to social cognition but does not explicitly state that a task-based fMRI was conducted or participant health status. Because it is potentially relevant to social processing in adults but information is insufficient from the abstract alone, include for full-text review to confirm task-based fMRI and eligible healthy adult sample.

fMRI study with 15 healthy male volunteers performing a social interaction/aggression (retaliation) task—fits social-related processing in humans. It reports primary data (not a review). Ages not explicitly stated but participants are healthy volunteers likely adults; abstract provides sufficient grounds to include for full-text review.

fMRI study in adult participants using a social-related task (socially-induced cognitive emotion regulation with a psychotherapist) assessing attachment and social functioning. Appears to involve healthy adults and is an original empirical study, not a review — meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study (n=38) used a social interaction task (virtual ball-toss) examining social reward and related neural activation (ventral striatum, precuneus). Participants appear to be healthy adults and the task probes social processing—meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI was conducted while participants performed a social-related task (attending to meaning of symbolic artifacts and viewing own vs others’ models), targeting social cognition in presumably healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis.

Primary fMRI study in healthy adults performing a visually based social judgment task (evaluation of social dominance in faces), directly addressing social cognitive processing. Participants are healthy adults and task is social-related; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

Functional MRI study investigating theory-of-mind/social processing (responses to unexpected social vs non-social events) in human participants. This addresses the review objective. The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit mention of clinical groups, so include for full-text review to confirm sample are healthy adults aged 17–65.

Original fMRI experiment in healthy human participants investigating person perception and mentalising (social cognition). Task pairs bodies/names with trait statements — a social-related task. Not a review/meta-analysis. Eligible for full-text data extraction.

Original fMRI study where participants performed a trustworthiness ratings task (social perception of others). Focuses on neural mechanisms of social cognition and race-related processing in presumably healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Functional MRI was used with 37 healthy adult participants (age within 17–65 range) during a social-evaluative task (watching approving/disapproving social videos). Study examines social processing neural responses and is not a review/meta-analysis.

This study used fMRI (block design) to measure neural responses to facial expressions—a social communication/perception task relevant to ‘perception and understanding of others’. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages; include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults (17–65).

This is an fMRI study of empathy/social cognition in healthy adult participants (20 adults) performing a social-related task (receiving empathic vs unempathic responses). It directly addresses social-related processing and is not a review or meta-analysis.

Task-based fMRI study investigating affective theory of mind (social processing) using a well-established ToM paradigm; 21 healthy adult participants analyzed. Directly addresses perception/understanding of others during scanning and is not a review article. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

fMRI study investigating guilt (a social-emotional/social-cognition process) in human participants, meeting the review topic. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (17–65), so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

Study targets social communication (right pSTS ROI, neurofeedback) and reports simultaneous task-related EEG–fMRI correlations, but the abstract does not specify that participants performed a defined social-related task nor participant demographics. Because task presence and healthy adult sample are unclear, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Abstract reports dyadic and monadic fMRI during live eye contact—a social interaction task relevant to the review. However, it does not specify participant ages or whether participants were healthy. Insufficient participant detail in abstract; include for full-text review.

fMRI study where participants (N=26) learned about others’ generosity (social task) with a non-social control; meets the review objective. Abstract does not explicitly state participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults (17–65). No exclusion criteria met.

Functional MRI MVPA used to examine neural representations of others' mental states (social cognition/perception of others). This meets the review objective of social-related fMRI in humans; although participant ages/health not specified in abstract, inclusion is appropriate (or include for full-text confirmation).

fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining neural processing of social interaction (mentalizing about a perceived live partner). Task involves social-communicative context; fits review’s social processing constructs. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study in healthy participants (n=26) performing empathy-evoking film clips with contextual manipulation—addresses social cognition. Meets review objective of social processing in healthy adults. Abstract does not report participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm age range and other eligibility details.

Human fMRI study where participants viewed faces of group members while performing a social cognition task; investigates perception/understanding of others and neural correlates. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although ages aren’t specified in the abstract, the study involves healthy adult social networks; include for full-text review to confirm age/health details.

The study used fMRI during an explicit social-attitude task (control of trust/distrust) in a healthy adult sample (n=60). It examines perception/understanding of others during scanning and is not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study directly investigates social-related processing (social vs nonsocial gestures) and social cognitive/affective neural responses. The abstract indicates typical healthy participant sample and no exclusion criteria apply. Fits the meta-analysis focus on fMRI studies of social processing in adults.

fMRI hyperscanning study of dyadic social interaction (mutual gaze, joint attention) — clearly a social-processing task in humans. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract implies healthy participant pairs and meets age range criteria; therefore fits inclusion.

fMRI study examining communicative speech acts (Requests vs Naming) involving social-interactive language processing; fits social communication domain. Abstract does not specify participant health/age, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study of social cognition (agency and communion) using a valence classification task—directly relevant to the review objective. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status; participant details are insufficient to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample (17–65).

fMRI study examining perception of others (racial in-group/out-group disgust)—a social processing task. Abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm eligibility.

fMRI was conducted during a Cyberball social exclusion task (social processing). Participants are human genotype groups (s/s vs l/l), implying healthy adult sample; study reports original fMRI data and neural correlates of social/romantic relationship satisfaction. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study combining explicit self-referential and implicit social stimulus paradigms in humans, addressing social processing. Abstract does not report participant ages or explicit ‘healthy’ status, but is not a review and likely involves healthy adults; given insufficient age/health detail, include for full-text review.

Primary fMRI study where participants read social vs non-social literary passages during functional neuroimaging, assessing theory-of-mind/social cognition. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not report ages explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health status.

fMRI study where participants watched and attended to violent social interactions—addresses social perception/understanding of others. Abstract implies healthy adult participants but does not state ages/health explicitly; include for full-text to confirm participant demographics and eligibility.

fMRI study with 30 healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (empathy for ingroup vs outgroup). Measures neural BOLD responses during a social cognition paradigm; fits review objective and inclusion criteria. Not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract reports fMRI of negative emotion processing but does not specify whether the task/stimuli were social (e.g., social interactions, faces, perception of others/self). Participants likely healthy adults, but insufficient detail to determine if the task meets the review’s social-related criteria. Per screening rules, include for full-text review to establish eligibility.

Abstract addresses Theory of Mind and medial PFC but does not state whether participants underwent an fMRI during a social task or report participant characteristics. Not a review/meta-analysis. Insufficient methodological detail in abstract—include for full-text review to confirm fMRI task and healthy adult sample.

This is an fMRI study where participants performed a gaze-following task (social attention), probing social constructs (in-group perceived similarity, social dominance orientation). Participants are healthy adult voters and the study examines social-related processing. It is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review, and meets the review objective and inclusion criteria.

Task-based fMRI study of social cognition (empathy and Theory of Mind) using the EmpaToM paradigm in healthy adult samples (N=90 and N=178). Directly addresses social processing in healthy adults and is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review.

fMRI study examining processing of social reputation (a social-related task) in male and female subjects, directly relevant to the review. Abstract implies healthy adult participants but does not state ages; include for full-text to confirm participant age range and health status.

Abstract reports an fMRI task (viewing social scenes) probing mental state attribution/mentalizing — a social-related process matching the review objective. No indication the sample includes clinical populations or that this is a review/meta-analysis. Include for full-text review to confirm sample age and health status.

fMRI study with healthy participants performing and rating imitation of actions, which is a social-related process (social interaction/communication/perception of others). Meets inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria evident.

fMRI was conducted in 164 healthy adult participants during an interactive mentalizing (Prisoner’s Dilemma) social task assessing attachment/mentalizing. This matches the review objective (social-related processing in healthy adults) and is not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study investigating neural networks for mental-state reasoning and action understanding, which maps onto social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Not a review. Abstract does not report participant ages/health status, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets healthy adult (17–65) criterion.

fMRI study measuring superior temporal sulcus responses to social and linguistic stimuli in human participants, matching the review objective. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm criteria.

fMRI study investigating social gaze and eye contact (perception/understanding of others). Conducted in human participants during an fMRI task; appears to involve healthy adults. Not a review. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social working memory and perspective-taking, directly relevant to social processing. It is not a review/meta-analysis. However, the abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so inclusion cannot be fully confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review.

fMRI study in young, healthy adults performing an incentive delay task with social rewards, directly assessing neural correlates of social reward processing. Meets inclusion criteria (social-related task; healthy participants aged within range). Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI experiment in healthy adults (no clinical populations reported) examining social-affective processes—mimicry, affiliation, and group membership—during a task; directly investigates social processing with task-based fMRI and is not a review or meta-analysis.

Functional MRI study examining neural correlates of social attribution (understanding others’ beliefs/motives), reporting DMPFC activation tied to social processing. Involves human participants and addresses social cognition in healthy adults; not a review. Fits inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing studies.

This is a theoretical/review paper discussing explanations of mirror-touch synesthesia; the abstract does not report an original fMRI experiment or describe a functional MRI task in healthy adult participants. It is not an empirical fMRI study addressing social-related processing, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes dyadic fMRI experiments investigating face-to-face social interaction and reciprocal eye-contact processing, which matches the review objective (social processing in fMRI). However, participant details (health status, ages 17–65) are not reported in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Hyperscanning fMRI study of real-time joint attention, directly examining social processing between interacting adults. While the abstract does not explicitly state participant ages or health status, it reports validation against real-world social behavior and replication, suggesting healthy adult samples; per guidance, include for full-text review if details are insufficient.

fMRI study with 18 participants performing social-cognition tasks (predicting others' behavior; theory-of-mind vs rule-based inference). This addresses perception/understanding of others in healthy adults and meets inclusion criteria. Not a review/meta-analysis and no exclusion criteria apparent. Age range not specified but participants are adults; include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study of deception in interactive, game-theoretic social tasks—addresses social cognition (perception/understanding of others, social communication). Human participants decided to lie or tell truth. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicit healthy status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study examining perception of emotions in dynamic crowds—clearly a social processing task in humans. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study examining perception of social interactions (person dyads) — aligns with social-related processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit statement that participants were healthy adults; insufficient detail to confirm inclusion criteria. Include for full-text review to verify participant health status and age range.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (n=37) performing a social communication task assessing feeling of being addressed; directly examines social processing. Age range not specified in abstract, but meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm ages and details.

Abstract reports dyadic fMRI during eye-contact social interaction (social-processing task). However participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract, so full-text review is needed to confirm inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports neuroimaging linking neural activity in brain regions involved in simulating others’ mental states with exposure to and retransmission of social language (a social-communication task).
